docs.abstract: Is there a formula to learning? Teachers may point the way, Bill Evans argues, “but a classroom is not a machine.”

headline.main: On Thinking About Talking About Teaching

docs.lead_paragraph: College is an antique car blazing through city streets. Historic license plate tacked on, a refinished interior that makes my father's belly hum deep down in doo-wop. It has a soul, so he says. The carburetor is beautiful to him, almost sexy. But it doesn't mean that to me. I wanted one at sixteen, but now, now I know better. My generation is less and less enamored with the steely shine of these fuel hungry beasts. I've watch them age, pedaling backwards through progress. As cars puffs out greenhouse gas, their exhaust rises and I see it spelling out my name into a future hazy with smog.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a child Ray Solomonoff developed what would become a lifelong passion for mathematical theorems, and as a teenager he became captivated with the idea of creating machines that could learn and ultimately think. In 1952 he met Marvin Minsky, a cognitive scientist who was also exploring the idea of machine learning, and John McCarthy, a young mathematician. And within four years, they and seven other scientists, as part of the original Dartmouth Summer Research Project, had founded a new field and given it a name: artificial intelligence.
docs.abstract: Ray Solomonoff, whose lifelong passion for mathematical theorems made him pioneer in using probability theory to solve artificial intelligence problems, dies at age 83; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At annual presentations in San Francisco, tech companies deluge potential customers with data on their progress in cloud computing, machine learning and artificial intelligence.
docs.abstract: Oracle, Salesforce, Google, Amazon and other tech companies hold autumn conferences in San Francisco and Atlanta, presenting their sales figures and future vision; this year's crop includes boasts about cloud computing, machine learning and artificial intelligence, with each firm asserting they are better at specific emerging technology than their biggest competitor.

docs.lead_paragraph: The processor, named TrueNorth, may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.
docs.abstract: IBM details TrueNorth computer chip it has developed in article published in journal Science; chip is inspired by human brain architecture and may one day exceed capabilities of today's supercomputers by mimicking the way brains recognize patterns.
